questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presented with purulent vaginal discharge associated with fever,malaise, and inguinal pain. A Pap smear revealed the following findings. What is thecausative agent?
questions.explanation: The given image of Pap smear shows cells with ground glass nuclei, viral inclusions,multinucleation, and margination of chromatin. These findings are characteristic of herpessimplex infection.Herpes simplex infection - Pap smearMultinucleated cellsand nuclear molding.Some infections of the female genital tract and their diagnostic features are given below:InfectionsHerpes simplexMolluscum contagiosumTrichomonas vaginalisGardnerella vaginaliSCandidaDiagnostic featuresGround glass nuclei with3M's:MultinucleationMarginationof chromatinMolding of nucleiPearly dome-shaped papule containing cells withcytoplasmic viral inclusionsStrawberry cervix; pear-shaped flagellated organism.Clue cells -squamous cells covered with a shaggy coating coccobacilliPseudospores and filamentous fungal hyphae

questions.question: What are the cystic remnants of mesonephric ducts in the cervix and vagina called?
questions.explanation: Cystic remnants of mesonephric ducts in the cervix and vagina are termed Gartner duct cysts.The mesonephric (Wolffian) ducts normally regress in females. Its remnants may persist intoadult life as epithelial inclusions adjacent to the ovaries, tubes, and uterus. In the cervix and863vagina, these ducts may be cystic and are termed Gartner duct cysts.The following images show the embryological development of the mesonephric duct and itspersistence into adult life.Embryology of Female reproductive organsAbdominal ostiumof uterine tubeMesonephrictubulesMCortical cordsof ovaryMesonephric ductUterine canalSinus tubercle.Remnants ofmesonephrictubulesEpoophoronParoophoronMesovariumRemnant ofmesonephric Gartner cyst-ductBOMARROWCorpusuteriCervixFornixUpper partof vagina

questions.question: 853The following histological image depicts a pathology in which of the following sites?
questions.explanation: The given histopathological image shows benign papillary projections covered with columnarsecretory epithelium and underlying myoepithelial cells. These are commonly seen in papillaryhidradenoma of the vulva.Papillary hidradenoma of the vulva -HistopathologyBenign papillaryprojectionsIt presents as a sharply circumscribed nodule, most commonly on the labia majora or interlabialfolds. Like the breast, the vulva also contains modified apocrine sweat glands. Its histologicappearance is identical to that of intraductal papilloma of the breast.864

questions.question: A 3-year-old girl presents with a mass protruding from the anterior vaginal wall that appearslike grape clusters. Histopathological examination reveals tadpole cells. What is the mostlikely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The most likely diagnosis is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (sarcoma botryoides).It is an uncommon vaginal tumor composed of malignant embryonal rhabdomyoblasts. It is mostfrequently found in infants and in children < 5 years of age. They are locally invasive tumorsthat cause death by penetration into the peritoneal cavity or by obstruction of the urinary tract.Grossly, polypoid, rounded, bulky masses that appear like grape clusters can be seen. Onmicroscopy, small tumor cells with oval nuclei, and small protrusions of cytoplasm from one endresembling a tennis racket (tadpole cells) can be seen. Beneath the vaginal epithelium, the tumorcells are crowded in a cambium layer, in the dermis.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding precursor squamous epithelial lesions of the cervix?

options.A: LSIL progress directly to invasive carcinoma
options.B: LSILs are 10 times more common than HSILs
options.C: HPV-16 is the most common HPV type in both LSIL and HSIL854
options.D: They progress to invasive carcinoma over many years

questions.explanation: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) does not progress directly to invasivecarcinoma. They initially progress to a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL), theninvasive carcinoma.The WHO currently recommends a 2-tier system of classification for cervical lesions - low andhigh-grade intraepithelial lesions (LSIL and HSIL). HPV-16 is the most common HPV typeassociated with both LSIL and HSILLSILS are 10 times more common than HSILS. Most of these lesions regressspontaneously. Progression to invasive carcinoma is unpredictable and can take place over years.

questions.question: What is the most common type of human papilloma virus causing cervical carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Human papillomavirus (HPV)-16 is the most common type of HPV causing cervical carcinoma. Itaccounts for almost 60% of cervical cancer cases.The ability of HPV to act as a carcinogen depends on the viral proteins E6 and E7. These proteinsinterfere with the activity of tumor-suppressor proteins that regulate cell growth and survival.• E6 binds with p53 gene and promote its degradation-• E7 - binds with RB gene and promotes its degradation

questions.question: A young woman comes to the gynecology OPD for cervical cancer screening. What is thestaining technique used for this?
questions.explanation: Cervical cancer screening test, commonly known as Pap smear, is stained using the Papanicolaoumethod.The time for initiating Pap smear screening is 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexualintercourse.865The sample is collected using Ayre's spatula and endocervical brush. 2 samples are taken:• 1st slide prepared from a sample taken from portio vaginalis of the cervix-• 2nd slide - prepared from the sample taken from the endocervix (transformation zone)95% ethanol is used as a fixative.It is a highly specific test. Colposcopic examination and biopsy are recommended in case ofabnormal Pap smear results.

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect about type I endometrial carcinoma?

options.A: It is associated with obesity and diabetes
options.C: Smoking is a high risk factor
options.D: It is caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation

questions.explanation: Smoking is strongly associated with mucinous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary, butnot endometrial carcinoma.Endometrial carcinoma is the most common invasive cancer of the female genital tract. Type 1endometrial carcinoma shows endometrioid morphology and is associated with:•Unopposed estrogen exposure (endometrial hyperplasia)●Obesity• Diabetes mellitus•HypertensionPTEN tumor-suppressor gene is mutated in approximately 20% of endometrial hyperplasias.Genomic sequencing of endometrial carcinoma has revealed 4 major molecular subtypes ofendometrioid and serous carcinomas:• Ultramutated/ POLE tumors mutations in DNA polymerase & (POLE)• Hypermutated/ MSI (microsatellite instability) tumors - mutations involving mismatch repairgenesCopy number low/ MSS (microsatellite stable) tumors - mutations involving the PI3K/AKTpathwayCopy number high/ serous-like tumors - TP53 mutations and numerous genomic copy numbervariants

questions.question: Which of the following is not a criterion to distinguish leiomyosarcoma from leiomyoma?
questions.explanation: The size of the tumor is not a criterion to distinguish between leiomyosarcoma and leiomyoma.The following features are seen in leiomyosarcomas:• Mitotic index - ≥10 mitoses / 10 hpf●• Nuclear atypia - in the presence of nuclear atypia, 5 mitoses / 10 hpf• Tumor cell necrosis -• Characterized by an abrupt transition from viable to non-viable areas866•Within the necrotic zones, atypical cells can be seen

questions.question: Histopathological examination of an ovarian mass sent to the pathology department revealedthe following. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.A: It is more common in women with low parity
options.B: The pathogenesis is related to family history and heritable mutations
options.C: High-grade tumors are associated with TP53 mutations

questions.explanation: The given image denotes Psammoma bodies which are a histopathological finding seen in ovarianpapillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma. These tumors are mostcommonly bilateral.Psammoma bodies -Serous cystadenoma ovaryPsammoma bodies -Serous cystadenoma ovaryConcentric calcificationThe majority of serous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline. But the serous carcinomas ofthe ovary include the most common malignant tumors of the ovary.Nulliparity, family history, and heritable mutations play a role in the development of thesetumors. Mutations in the oncogenes KRAS, BRAF, or ERBB2 result in low-grade tumors, andmutation in TP53 is associated with high-grade tumors.867There is a higher frequency of carcinoma in women with low parity. Women on oral contraceptivepills or those who have undergone tubal ligation are at a lower risk. The marker for ovariantumors is CA-125.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding mucinous tumors of the ovary?

options.C: It occurs principally in middle adult life
options.D: Mutation of the KRAS proto-oncogene is seen

questions.explanation: The vast majority of mucinous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline tumors (notmalignant).It occurs principally in middle adult life and is rare before puberty and after menopause. Thesurface of the ovary is rarely involved, they are rarely bilateral. It is associated with the mutationof KRAS proto-oncogene.Grossly it is multiloculated and filled with sticky, gelatinous fluid (rich in glycoproteins).

questions.question: 856A 30-year-old woman underwent an evaluation for an abdominal mass. A laparotomy wasdecided upon for the removal of the mass. The gross appearance of the mass is as follows.Histopathological examination revealed no malignant change. What is the most likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given scenario and image showing unilocular cystic space containing hair and sebaceousmaterial are suggestive of mature teratoma.Mature Teratoma Gross specimen868Mature Teratoma - Gross specimenSebaceousmaterialUnilocularcystic spaceHairsDermoid cysts or mature teratomas are benign tumors, usually found in young women during theactive reproductive years. It is bilateral in 10% to 15% of cases.Microscopically, the cyst wall is composed of tissues from all 3 germ layers. This includesstratified squamous epithelium, with underlying sebaceous glands, hair shafts, and other skinadnexal structures. Sometimes cartilage, bone, thyroid, and neural tissue can be seen.About 1% of the dermoids undergo malignant transformation, most commonly to squamous cellcarcinoma. It can also transform into other cancers (e.g., thyroid carcinoma, melanoma).Dermoid cyst - Histopathology869Dermoid cyst - HistopathologyHair follicleFat tissueQRespiratoryepitheliumSmooth muscleMicrocystThe component tissue of immature malignant teratomas resembles embryonal and immature fetaltissue. It often consists of primitive neuroepithelial cells. The tumor is found chiefly inprepubertal adolescents and young women, the mean age being 18 years.Monodermal or specialized teratomas:• Struma ovarii - composed entirely of mature thyroid tissue, which may be functional and causehyperthyroidism.•Ovarian carcinoid - arises from intestinal tissue, may be functional causing carcinoid syndromein the absence of hepatic metastasis

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presented to the gynecology OPD with a history of abdominal pain anddistension of abdomen. Ultrasound imaging revealed tumor in the right ovary. Serum level ofinhibin was raised. The histopathology of the tumor is given below. What is the most likelydiagnosis?857
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and histopathology showing Call-Exner bodies are suggestive ofgranulosa cell tumor.Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic materialresembling immature follicles. Additionally, small, cuboidal to polygonal cells are seen which maygrow in anastomosing cords, sheets, or strands.870Call-Exner bodies - Granulosa cell tumorCall-Exner bodies - Granulosa cell tumorGlandlike structures resemblingimmature folliclesGranulosa cell tumors are composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells of a developing ovarianfollicle. It can be of adult and juvenile types. Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a productof granulosa cells, are associated with this tumor.Mutations of the FOXL2 gene are seen in most adult granulosa cell tumors.

questions.question: A 12-year-old girl, who is yet to attain her menarche, presents with an ovarian mass. Herserum biomarkers are normal except for elevated AFP. Staging laparotomy was performedand the histopathological image is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller Duval bodies aresuggestive of endodermal sinus tumors. It is also known as yolk sac tumor.The Schiller-Duval body is a glomerulus-like structure composed of a central blood vesselenveloped by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.871It is the second most common malignant tumor of germ cell origin. It is a unilateral tumor usuallyaffecting children or young women.Yolk sac tumor - HistopathologyYolk sac tumor - HistopathologySchiller-Duval body

questions.question: Which of the following are sex cord-stromal tumors?
questions.explanation: Sex cord-stromal tumors include the following:• Granulosa cell tumor• Sertoli cell tumor• FibromaBrenner tumor is an epithelial tumor and dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor.872

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman presented with bilateral adnexal masses. Histopathologicalexamination of the resected specimen showed sheets of mucin-producing signet-ring cells.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and histopathology findings are suggestive of metastatic carcinoma ofthe ovary or Krukenberg tumor.It can arise from primary carcinomas of the stomach (most common), colon, appendix, and breast(invasive lobular carcinoma). It is often bilateral and on microscopy shows mucin-ladensignet-ring cells with eccentric hyperchromatic nuclei.Krukenberg tumor of the ovary -HistopathologyKrukenberg tumor of the ovary -HistopathologyMucin-ladensignet-ring cellsMetastatic tumors of the ovary include:• Tumors of Müllerian origin (most common) - the uterus, fallopian tube, contralateral ovary, orpelvic peritoneum•Tumors of extra-Müllerian tumors - breast and gastrointestinal tract carcinomas• Pseudomyxoma peritonei - derived from appendiceal tumors• Krukenberg tumor873

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman was diagnosed with molar pregnancy and underwent suction andevacuation. The resected specimen is shown below. Histopathological examination revealedthin-walled, cystic structures consisting of hydropic villi with extensive trophoblasticproliferation along its entire circumference. Immunohistochemistry was negative for p57.Which of the following is false about this condition?859

options.A: The genetic material is completely maternally derived
options.B: Embryo dies very early in development and therefore is usually not identified
options.C: It is associated with a 2.5% risk of subsequent choriocarcinoma

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and image showing grapelike vesicles are suggestive of a completemole. It results from the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes, and as aresult, the genetic material is completely paternally derived.Hydatidiform mole - Gross appearanceHydatidiform mole - Gross appearanceGrape-like vesiclesThe pathogenesis of complete mole is as follows:• Androgenesis (most common) - 46XX karyotype stemming from the duplication of the geneticmaterial of 1 sperm•Dispermy - 46XX or 46XY karyotype due to fertilization of an empty egg by 2 spermsMicroscopically, thin-walled, cystic, grapelike structures consisting of hydropic villi are seen.Trophoblastic proliferation involving the entire circumference of the villi is seen.874The embryo dies very early in development and, therefore, is usually not identified. Patients havea 2.5% risk of subsequent choriocarcinoma and a 15% risk of the persistent or invasive mole.The following image shows the pathogenesis of molar pregnancy.232323 x23 X/YMolar pregnancyEmpty ovum23 X/YEmpty ovum2323Normal pregnancy4646 XY / 46 XXChromosomeduplication2346232346 XXX(Homozygous)46— 46 XX / 46 XY—(Homozygous)(Heterozygous).Complete mole2323 2323232369Triploid partial mole69 XXX / 69 XXY / 69XYY(rare)Partial moleOMARROW

questions.question: A 26-year-old woman with a positive pregnancy test presented with vaginal bleeding in thefirst trimester. On examination, grape-like vesicles were noted in the vagina. A transvaginalultrasound revealed the presence of fetal tissues. A suction evacuation was performed. Whatis the most likely karyotype of the evacuated material?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with grape-like vesicles in the vagina and the presence of fetal tissueson transvaginal ultrasound are suggestive of partial mole. The karyotype in a partial moleis triploid (e.g., 69XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92XXXY).It results from the fertilization of an egg with 2 sperms. There is an increased risk of persistentmolar disease but it is not associated with choriocarcinoma.Given below is an image showing the karyotype of molar pregnancy.232323 x23 X/YMolar pregnancyEmpty ovum23 X/YEmpty ovum2323Normal pregnancy4646 XY / 46 XXChromosomeduplication234646 XX(Homozygous)4646 XX / 46 XY-(Homozygous)Complete mole232323232323(Heterozygous)69Triploid partial mole69 XXX / 69 XXY / 69XYY(rare)Partial mole©MARROW875

questions.question: What is the most common site of metastasis in gestational choriocarcinoma?
questions.explanation: Lungs are the most common site of metastasis in gestational choriocarcinoma.It is followed by the vagina, brain, liver, bone, and kidney in descending order of frequency.Gestational choriocarcinomas are malignant neoplasm of trophoblastic cells derived from apreviously normal or abnormal pregnancy, such as an extrauterine ectopic pregnancy. The hCGlevels are elevated to levels above those encountered in hydatidiform moles. Itshows hematogenous spread. It is rapidly invasive and metastasizes widely.Gestational choriocarcinomas are chemosensitive whereas non-gestational choriocarcinomas arechemoresistant.

questions.question: The genetic profile of malignant mixed Müllerian tumors resembles that of:
questions.explanation: Malignant mixed Müllerian tumors (MMMTs) are carcinosarcomas whose genetic profileclosely resembles endometrial carcinomas.They involve mutations in the same genes - PTEN, TP53, and PIK3CA. The usual geneticalterations found in sarcomas are absent in MMMTs.MMMTs are endometrial adenocarcinomas with malignant mesenchymal components. Themesenchymal component may resemble uterine mesenchymal elements (stromal sarcoma,leiomyosarcoma) or contain heterologous malignant cell types (striated muscle, cartilage, adiposetissue, and bone).It occurs in postmenopausal women and presents with bleeding. It is associated with a pooroutcome.

questions.question: Which of the following are the components of Meig's syndrome?
questions.explanation: Meigs' syndrome triad includes the following:•Solid benign ovarian tumor (fibroma)• Right-sided hydrothorax• Ascites disappears after the removal of the tumorPseudo-Meigs' syndrome is characterized by the following:• Non-malignant ascites• Pleural effusion•-Pelvic tumors other than solid benign ovarian tumorsNote: Ovarian fibroma is also associated with nevoid basal cell carcinoma. This association isknown as Gorlin syndrome.876

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman was operated for an ovarian mass and the sample was sent forhistopathological examination. The findings are given below. Which of the following is falseabout the given condition?861

options.B: It expresses OCT-3, OCT4, and NANOG
options.D: It occurs in patients with gonadal dysgenesis

questions.explanation: The given histopathological image shows large cells with clear cytoplasm (fried egg appearance),tumor cells arranged in sheets, and cords of fibrous stroma infiltrated by lymphocytes. Thesefindings are suggestive of dysgerminoma. It is highly responsive to radiotherapy.Dysgerminoma - HistopathologyDysgerminoma - HistopathologyFibrous stromacontaining lymphocytesCells withclear cytoplasmDysgerminomas are the ovarian counterparts of testicular seminoma. They may occur inchildhood, but most commonly occur in the 2-3rd decades. It may occur in patients with gonadaldysgenesis, including pseudohermaphroditism. The majority of these tumors are unilateral. Theyexpress OCT-3, OCT4, and NANOG.All dysgerminomas are malignant, but the degree of histologic atypia is variable. Only aboutone-third of these lesions are aggressive. These neoplasms are responsive to chemoradiation, andoverall survival exceeds 80%.877878
